comment_data.body:
I haven't published it yet, but I was working on a library with high level lua bindings some time ago:
```lua
local nv = require('nv')

-- get a buffer handle
-- everything is also accessible through nv.buf.* for the current buffer
local buf = nv.buf(4)
buf.type = 'nofile'

P(buf.nr, buf.name, buf.displayname) --> 1, "/home/user/script.lua", "script.lua"
P(buf.valid, buf.loaded, buf.filetype) --> true, true, "lua"

buf.opt.number = true
print(buf.opt.number) --> true

-- get/set lines
P(buf[0]) --> "local nv = require('nv')"
P(buf[-1]) --> "end"

-- get/set marks
P(buf.mark.m) --> { 13, 0 }

-- normal mode buffer mapping
buf.map.n('<CR>', function()
  print('sup')
end)

-- BufEnter autocommand
buf.on.BufEnter(function()
  print('BufEnter')
end)

for _, b in pairs(nv.buf.list({ listed = true })) do
  print(b) --> nv.buf(1)
end
```

I was discussing this on the Matrix yesterday. I will be really happy if this is something the neovim wants to add because I'm already doing something similar for my plugin. Also, I'm happy to help with this!

I prefer the new API to be something like:

```lua
local b0 = vim.buffer:new(true, false) -- create a new buffer

-- get buffer by IDs or name?
local b1 = vim.buffer(0) -- or vim.buffer[0]
local b2 = vim.buffer(1) -- or vim.buffer[1]
local b3 = vim.buffer('my-buffer-name') -- or vim.buffer['my-buffer-name']

-- window
local w0 = vim.window:new() -- create a new window
local w1 = vim.window(1000) -- or vim.window[1000]

-- tabs
local t1 = vim.tab(1) -- or vim.tab[1]

vim.pretty_print(b1:name()) --> "my awesome buffer"
vim.pretty_print(b1:valid()) --> true
vim.pretty_print(b1:loaded()) --> true

-- set options
b2:option.set {
  option1 = true,
  option2 = false,
  ...
}
-- or individually
b2:option.set("option1", true)
b2:option.set("option2", false)
-- and get
b2:option.get("option1")
b2:option.get("option2")

-- keymaps
b2:keymap.set("n", "<Leader>m", function() ... end)
b2:keymap.del("n", "<Leader>m")

-- events
b2:on({ "BufferEnter" }, function() ... end)

-- attach to buffer
b2:attach {
  on_lines = function(...) print(...) end,
}
```

The only thing I don't know how to be the best way to implement will be the extmarks and highlights. Extmarks and highlights are something that it's related to a `buffer` but we can have the namespace from the current window? Maybe we can have a context for a given buffer? _(Not sure)_

```lua
local ns = vim.api.nvim_create_namespace("mynamespace")
local b = vim.buffer[0]

-- option1: setting the namespace for the buffer?
b:namespace.set(ns)
b:extmark.set {
  ...extmark options
}

-- option2: using the namespace in the call?
b:extmark.set(ns, {
  ...extmark options
})
```

But I think if my buffer is being shown inside a given window (that have a namespace attached to it), I expect my buffer to have the same namespace

```lua
local ns = vim.api.nvim_create_namespace("ns")

local w = vim.window:new {
  namespace = ns,
}

local b = vim.buffer:new()

w:buffer.set(b)

w:open { focus = true }

vim.pretty_print(b:namespace.get()) --> id from "ns"
```

That is all my thoughts in this topic after spending a lot of time doing buffer and window stuff inside my plugins. I hope we can get something similar implemented. Will be really ergonomic to write plugins!

Thanks all in advance!

see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/20669 , specifically https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/20669#issuecomment-1279862492

> We should instead think about higher-level interfaces and patterns.

Let's avoid syntactic sugar around the RPC API. We need thoughtful, higher-level abstractions in Lua.

> see #20669 , specifically [#20669 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/20669#issuecomment-1279862492)
> 
> > We should instead think about higher-level interfaces and patterns.
> 
> Let's avoid syntactic sugar around the RPC API. We need thoughtful, higher-level abstractions in Lua.

100% agreed with you, Justin. Just a syntax sugar API will not solve all the problems and maybe will introduce more work synchronizing all the APIs.

I'm happy to help with this, but I'm not sure how to start doing these abstractions. I'll try to understand where and how this can be done.

Thank you for letting me know about those issues, really nice!
